body: I don't jitter click and my best on a click test is about 7.5 clicks per second. I can sort of jitter click, and I can tell its a lot faster but I just can't control it. I don't know whether it's my mouse (I have a cheap Logitech M185). So would a gaming mouse help me jitter click or should I stick with this mouse and practice or get a gaming mouse?

replies.body: Usually if you practice a lot or play games/programs where you have to click fast, it can help improve the speed. On a $10 mouse I get 10 CPS, but on a Razer I get around 11

replies.body: Naw i can full on jitter at 17cps however i find that clicking at 8-11cps with better aim is far better for pvp. Also jitterclicking = Arthuritis. Yes you should get a gaming mouse what is your budget? I use a cheap £35 roccat kova and it really does the job! Love it! Getting a gaming mouse is  a high priority especially if you get low fps like me.

replies.body:
When I jitter click, I keep a light grip on my mouse and keep my thumb off of it, but I put my palm on the heel of the mouse. The rubber grip on my mouse helps me keep it under control. It generally just helps me aim and jitter at the same time. However, practice is key to perfecting jitter clicking.

Gaming mice definitely helps for clicking imo, since their buttons have a better feel and are easier to click. 
I use this mouse: http://www.amazon.com/CM-Storm-Recon-Ambidextrous-Multicolor/dp/B009JZ04BC

I got it for around $32, but I guess the price has been raised. I've heard Razer and Logitech were good for doing stuff like this.
